Description: Tusk cosmetic spoon: in the form of a duck, which turns her head to offer a fish to the two ducklings which ride on her back. The duck's eyes were carved to hold inlays, now lost. The closed wings form the lid of the spoon and swivel to either side so that the bowl hollowed from the bird's body might be used to receive a scented fat or oil. In order to stabilize the lid when closed, a knob is set at its end, around which a cord could be tied to join it with a corresponding knob at the very back of the duck's body.
Curator's comments: The motif of the duck in connection with cosmetic items is particularly characteristic of the later 18th Dynasty. Bibliography: M.A. Corzo, 'Nefertari Luce d'Egitto' (Rome, 1994), p. 162 [33]; 'Egyptian Treasures' [exhibition catalogue] (Shanghai, 1999), pp. 246-247 [75].

For such fine 'cosmetic spoons', typically found in tombs though examples have been found in temples, see Egypt’s Golden Age (exhibition catalogue, Boston, 1982): 207-15 [no.260 is a duck-shaped example].
Bibliographic references: Andrews 2000 / Egyptian Treasures from the British Museum (p.188-189)
